body: Triggered CI `#50` which shows 3 test failures, none of them seem to be related with these changes.

I've proposed an alternative implementation based on @tolbertam suggestion in https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CASSANDRA-19984 and I've re-triggered CI `#51`.

Patch for trunk: https://github.com/apache/cassandra/pull/3604 and CI `#52`.
@michaelsembwever all changes done.

> Triggered CI #50  â€¦  for trunk: https://github.com/apache/cassandra/pull/3604 and CI #52.

Don't forget the two artefacts from the internal CI runs must be shared so others can verify it (if they choose to).

attached to ticket:
- https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/13072025/CASSANDRA-19984_50_%2350_ci_summary.html
- https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/13072026/CASSANDRA-19984_50_%2350_results_details.tar.xz
- https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/13072032/CASSANDRA-19984_50_%2351_ci_summary.html
- https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/13072031/CASSANDRA-19984_50_%2351_results_details.tar.xz
- https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/13072030/CASSANDRA-19984_trunk_%2352_ci_summary.html
- https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/13072029/CASSANDRA-19984_trunk_%2352_results_details.tar.xz

@michaelsembwever thanks for attaching the results. I didn't forget, my plan was to add those at the end of the day after CI had finished. No unit test was added as I was unsure on the final implementation. This second approach was much better than I initially thought. If there's no further feedback, I'll work out adding the right tests for this.

CI [j8](https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/bereng/cassandra/1205/workflows/b3716eef-0dbe-4866-9417-08fb00d400cd) and [j11](https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/bereng/cassandra/1205/workflows/dfc35f37-b0de-45e8-8c8f-86575540a636)

@michaelsembwever I've updated this PR according to the discussion done in https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CASSANDRA-19984 . An unit test was added to ensure existent functionality is not broken and that we have some coverage on the newly introduced API.

If this change is ok, I'll update the PR for trunk and CI results.

@masokol , @emolsson , @itskarlsson , @tommystendahl , @etedpet , @jwaeab , @VictorCavichioli , @SajidRiaz138 , @ch1bbe , @ArcturusMengsk , @DanielwEriksson , @manmagic3 

as contributors to https://github.com/Ericsson/ecchronos we would very much appreciate any last-minute-pre-CEP-vote review to this PR for Cassandra's new repair solution.   (more technical/code review will continue post-CEP vote.)

CEP:
https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/CASSANDRA/CEP-37+Apache+Cassandra+Unified+Repair+Solution

Design doc: 
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1CJWxjEi-mBABPMZ3VWJ9w5KavWfJETAGxfUpsViPcPo/edit?tab=t.0#heading=h.r112r46toau0

Hi,

I think this looks promising! I have a few points:
* Combine ranges instead of splitting - in ecChronos we saw huge improvements in some scenarios (when the data is low or empty tables) compared to repairing 1 vnode at a time. This improvement scaled with amount of vnodes, although it might've been related to overhead due to running repairs through JMX. Not sure but might be worth investigating.
* Major versions, during major version upgrades like 3 -> 4 we weren't supposed to run repairs. If Cassandra plans to keep this then it would be nice for repairs to automatically pause during major version upgrades.
* Observabliity, i saw there're metrics but it would also be nice to see repair status with nodetool.
* Repair priority per table, not per node.

Thanks, @masokol, for the review! Please find my response here:

> - Combine ranges instead of splitting - in ecChronos we saw huge improvements in some scenarios (when the data is low or empty tables) compared to repairing 1 vnode at a time. This improvement scaled with amount of vnodes, although it might've been related to overhead due to running repairs through JMX. Not sure but might be worth investigating.

1. Generally, empty tables or tables with a small amount of data runs through pretty fast, in seconds, so it is not a major issue for smaller/empty tables.
2. The current framework already has support to combine ranges through a setting ([src/java/org/apache/cassandra/repair/autorepair/AutoRepair.java:266](https://github.com/apache/cassandra/pull/3598/files#diff-b9a857a0f20a2f239d5e27511e4db19c87704faccb17b5205b5406e69ea08f52R266))

> - Major versions, during major version upgrades like 3 -> 4 we weren't supposed to run repairs. If Cassandra plans to keep this then it would be nice for repairs to automatically pause during major version upgrades.

This is a great suggestion, and the framework can be enhanced easily - I just filed a new sub-ticket [CASSANDRA-20013](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CASSANDRA-20013) to track this 

> - Observabliity, i saw there're metrics but it would also be nice to see repair status with nodetool.

There is already a new nodetool command that would print the current status. Please take a look at it [here](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1CJWxjEi-mBABPMZ3VWJ9w5KavWfJETAGxfUpsViPcPo/edit?tab=t.0#bookmark=id.887cdlihznq7).

> - Repair priority per table, not per node.

Currently, it will repair the tables randomly, but it can be enhanced to add a priority as a CQL table property that an end user can configure, which can also be enhanced easily. Just added this enhancement to the ticket mentioned above.

Committed as https://github.com/apache/cassandra/commit/32030e4fa35813803ebaa93e1aa54964ae2b0cf5

I think all the method calls like `getCapacity() != 0` and `getCapacity() == 0` should be replaced by a method in the DatabaseDescriptor class that is clear and easy to use whether a cache is enabled or not. We should avoid using `getCapacity` method to check such a condition. This is true for the trunk, 5.x, 4.x

Committed as https://github.com/apache/cassandra/commit/85048b20196e2c7fddc142de9095ef6e9f82e837

The main thing blocking my +1 is the `txn_blocked_by` table.  We either need to move it back where it was, or change JVM-Dtest to handle the changes.

My stance is `txn_blocked_by` should move back and if there are concerns about the table we should address them.  If there is a valid believe that this table should not be exposed in prod in the current state I am fine moving it (though I disagree).

@JeetKunDoug Will close this PR without merge since the other parallel PR is reviewed already by Stefan and CI build is green out of it. Sorry for keeping two PRs open. Didn't realize that I accidentally opened this PR prior to opening PRs on myfork to get your initial reviews. Ref: https://github.com/apache/cassandra/pull/3638

@smiklosovic I moved the JMX test method to a utility class and added `ERROR` level log for each error before adding it to the suppressed list. Let us see if this helps us identify flakiness in the test.

CI [survives](https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/bereng/cassandra/1241/workflows/68a3cb41-6011-4b90-947c-b6066ab7cad6/jobs/44906) 5K repeats whereas it [failed](https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/bereng/cassandra/1240/workflows/511ba140-4ccb-45a9-954e-b745382dce50/jobs/44798) before

If you're OK with it, I might actually refactor some of this code into accord-core so we can share with `InMemoryCommandStore`? The `CommandsForRanges` abstraction (and `Summary`) could go there, so we can test that it makes correct recovery decisions.

Want to mention it before I do it, to minimise redundant review work given will create a lot of (effectively no-op) deltas again.

I also noticed we weren't using any of the historic range transactions here. So I've had them create summary entries. This would be another thing that's good to test, as this was likely a long standing correctness bug. Hopefully the simulator will be up and running properly soon and begin exercising these bugs properly, but perhaps also Alex's semi-integrated burn test will include the integration `CommandsForRanges` and spot problems here.

> The CommandsForRanges abstraction (and Summary) could go there, so we can test that it makes correct recovery decisions.

thats fine by me.  That was the original plan when I wrote that but we wanted to keep it in C*, so I don't have issues pushing an abstraction to accord-core to make it easier to maintain both sides

Can you re-add the logic from `test/unit/org/apache/cassandra/index/accord/RouteIndexTest.java` in `poc/key-recovery-sees-ranges`?  The current stateful test for range index just gets extended to do key search as well

> thats fine by me. That was the original plan when I wrote that but we wanted to keep it in C*, so I don't have issues pushing an abstraction to accord-core to make it easier to maintain both sides

So, I've had to look at some related logic as part of my burn test run cleanup, and I have there also made steps to better unify the `SafeCommandStore` implementations, so I'll probably do the work to unify there instead.

FYI if you want to retain a max tenuring threshold of 1, you can specify -XX:ZTenuringThreshold=1 with generational ZGC. But honestly it will probably figure things out automatically anyway.
Committed manually
Hello, can i take up this issue?

Here is a patch to fix the empty range issue https://github.com/dcapwell/cassandra/tree/feedback/pr-3694

To dump the history here:

1) single node JVM Dtest cluster had `Long.MAX_VALUE` for the token which caused TCM to produce an "empty" range (containing 0 partitions).. by decoupling Accord from TCM ranges we can merge touching ranges and avoid this issue.
2) TokenRange overrides `someIntersectingRoutingKey` to avoid using `+Inf` as the home key, but this is a valid key so removed... by fixing the above this will now match the what is present in the stores (the empty range got dropped so we didn't have +Inf in stores, only shards)

> Hello, can i take up this issue?

feel free to left your review comments

https://github.com/instaclustr/cassandra/commit/a58c9a73d9ada9f74c169e223170f3b7955b6360

What I did was that SortBy enum takes default sorting direction and then it implements abstract method which is sorting.

Then you can just take sortBy and sort very comfortably by one line.

What I like the most is that we are logically coupling sorting logic to respective sorting enum. Currently we do have an enum, but methods are separated from that and it is more complex than it could be.
I like this approach of using enum for sorting.
@smiklosovic I have updated the code for the above approach
@manish-m-pillai great, I will start CI and I will post the results in the ticket.
